For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

content:
Don't give up yet. Thunderbird may have just created a new profile, and left the old one alone. If you're comfortable with Windows (assuming you use Windows0, you can invoke File Manager and go to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles and see if there are multiple profile folders. If so, look in those profiles in the Imapmail and Mail folders and Mail\Local Folder to see if your accounts are there. If so, we can assist in getting them back.

On your backup question, the safest approach is to use Windows File Manager. To do that: - exit thunderbird (VERY important to avoid a corrupted backup) - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media Then, should you ever need to restore, - with thunderbird installed and not running - copy the backed-up thunderbird folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbird folder.

I do a backup at least weekly and keep the past three copies. And I've never lost any messages.

content:
Have you allowed remote content? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/remote-content-in-messages

Beyond that, historically there have been issues with antivirus products blocking images that all originate from the same place.

Finally if the images are loaded with scripts, Thunderbird will simply not run them, so that makes your mail more secure and makes it way harder for the sender to track your every click. It does however mean some aggressive vendors send mail you have to view in a web browser to see images.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Lets start with your actual issue.

If you are getting messages about exceeding your daily limit of emails, that will be from the company providing your email server. Usually the company name after the @ in your email address.

As to the second part, going back is most unwise. It is not recommended even for those with a technical bent and a knowledge of how Thunderbird stores it's data locally.

However My mail lists have remained visually basically unchanged for the last 15 years, so I wonder if you are using the new card view and don't like it. I certainly don't.

This is a sample of card view for one of my lists.

This is the same list in the list view that existed prior to version 115

This is the menu that is used to switch between them.

I am only guessing about the view, please post back if I have it all wrong.
creator: MattAuSupport
